Award.AwardTitle: UPGRADE OF ELECTRON MICROPROBE SX-100 AT OREGON STATE UNIVERSITY IN THE COLLEGE OF EARTH, OCEAN, AND ATMOSPHERIC SCIENCES
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Division of Earth Sciences Instrumentation and Facilities program award supports upgrade of an aging 2004 CAMECA SX-100 electron microprobe. The Oregon State University (OSU) Electron Microprobe (EMP) Laboratory is an open analytical facility and is used for research across a broad spectrum of sciences, and for undergraduate and graduate student research and education. The award is also jointly supported by the Division of Ocean Sciences Marine Geology and Geophysics Program. The electron microprobe is a research tool capable of determining microspatially resolved chemical compositions of solid materials that help researchers address a wide variety of scientific and engineering problems. These include problems in the fields of geology, metallurgy, solid state physics, mechanical and chemical engineering, electronics, biology, and physical chemistry. The laboratory has formed an important component of the OSU research infrastructure and underpins the research activities of a diverse user base, including geoscientists, engineers, biologists, material scientists and environmental scientists.

Upgrade of the EMP will provide indispensable services to the entire OSU community, to other academic institutions, state and federal agencies, and to a large number of industry collaborators and partners both nationally and internationally. Upgrade of the OSU electron microprobe is necessary for several reasons: 1) the current equipment is now over 15 years old and is experiencing reduced performance and intermittent problems with electronic components, spectrometers and vacuum systems; 2) a full-functioning machine will allow faculty and students to meet current demands for electron microprobe analyses at OSU, providing increased user access, and improving and increasing hands-on laboratory experiences for graduate and undergraduate students; and 3) upgrading the EMP our electron microprobe will provide an important impetus for future research activities including studies of magma genesis, differentiation and volcanic hazards, paleontological investigations of Neoproterozoic and early Paleozoic animal fossilization processes, and studies of the thermal and impact history of asteroid materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funds from this project were used to upgrade an aging 2004 CAMECA SX-100 electron microprobe used for research, primarily in the Earth and Ocean Sciences and related disciplines, and for undergraduate and graduate student research and education.

The OSU Electron Microprobe (EMP) Laboratory was established jointly by College of Oceanic and Atmospheric Sciences (COAS) and by the Department of Geosciences in 1988, and it resides in the College of Earth, Ocean, and Atmospheric Sciences (CEOAS). It is operated as an open analytical facility, and the laboratory has formed an important component of the OSU research infrastructure underpinning the research activities of a diverse user base, including Geoscientists, Engineers, Biologists, Material Scientists and Environmental Scientists. To facilitate such research and collaboration, since 2004 the OSU EMP facility added remote use capabilities allowing students and researchers from a range of institutions to use the instrument both nationally and internationally.  As such, the laboratory provides indispensable services to the entire OSU community, to national academic institutions, state and federal agencies, and to many industry collaborators and partners; collectively serving over 200 investigator groups over the last 20+ years. The OSU EMP Laboratory facility has also provided high-level technical support to help collaborating faculty to develop analytical procedures, find standard materials and train graduate students. The laboratory has worked with hundreds of graduate students from five different OSU colleges as well as researchers from over a dozen state and federal agencies and over 100 industry collaborators and partners.

The Oregon State University Electron Microprobe Laboratory currently utilizes and maintains a CAMECA SX-100 Electron which is equipped with 5 wavelength dispersive spectrometers (WDS) and one energy dispersive spectrometer (EDS) with thin window for light element detection. This instrument also has high intensity dispersive crystals for high sensitivity trace element analysis, and a high precision sample stage with 0.1 um stepping capability. The probe is equipped with CAMECA Peak Site analysis and imaging software, and it is capable of quantitative analyses from Z = 4 (Be) to 92 (U) uranium. It has the capability for high-resolution elemental mapping and trace element analysis at low concentrations (generally to 100’s of ppm). The probe has a high speed back scattered electron (BSE) imaging system, transmitted and reflected light imaging, and automated calibration and analysis. The EMP Laboratory maintains a wide range of nationally recognized and in-house calibration standards for quantitative analyses of silicates, sulfides, carbonates, oxides, and alloys.

The OSU EMP Laboratory is utilized in a variety of research endeavors. In terms of current and proposed research that depend on microprobe data, the new instrumentation has allowed us to investigate:

Mineral Identification and characterization: allows researchers to determine the detailed chemical composition of unknown minerals from geological samples. This allows researchers to better understand geological processes, such as magma differentiation or ore genesis through variations, or lack thereof, in mineral compositions.

Corrosion analysis in Materials Science: allows researchers to investigate the chemical changes in the metal surface and the formation of oxide or corrosion layers to help improve materials' longevity in different environments.

Alloy characterization heat treatment effects on the metals: allows researchers the ability to understand the relationship between composition, phase formation, and mechanical properties and the effect of heating alloys on compositions/phases/mechanical properties for use in various applications.

Petrographic studies of rocks: allows researchers to determine the mineralogical and chemical composition of a geological sample. In this way, researchers determine the petrogenesis (formation of rocks), the relationships between mineral composition, texture, and rock formation, the data of which can used for geological history reconstruction.

Ore deposit exploration: allows researchers the ability to understand the distribution of valuable elements (e.g., Au, Cu, Zn). This allows researchers to characterize ore mineralogy, distribution of ore bodies, and trace element signatures to assist in exploration and exploitation of mineral resources.
